text: Roles involved in the agile development process (e.g., Scrum Master, Product Owner, Developer, Tester) exist in the organization.
Project teams include a Product Owner, who is responsible for representing the Customer and actively participates in the projects.
The scope of the project is defined gradually, using the Product Backlog (or equivalent artifact).
Effort estimation is performed by (or together with) the development team considering short activities to implement a set of selected requirements (and not the project as a whole).
Cost estimation is established based on the effort estimation and considers the effort needed to implement a selected set of requirements (and not the project as a whole).
To deliver value to the customer, requirements are defined and prioritized according to customer needs, are periodically reviewed, and changes are absorbed into iterations of the development process.
The development process is performed iteratively, in short cycles (e.g., 2 weeks), in which selected project requirements recorded in a Sprint Backlog (or equivalent artifact) are developed.
The customer receives new versions of the product frequently (after one or more short development cycles), including new functionality defined according to customer needs.
The organization has clear acceptance criteria for software requirements and they are used to evaluate the artifacts (e.g., functionality) produced and define if they are concluded.
The organization has at least one person (e.g. Software Architect, Tech Lead or Quality Analyst) responsible for the quality of the produced artifacts, including the final product.

The team frequently (e.g., daily, every two or three days) reflects on the development progress within the scope of what has been defined for the current time-box and adjusts tasks if necessary (e.g., stand-up meetings)
The team frequently meets to discuss improvements to the product, process, or tools during the projects (e.g., in retrospective meetings).
The team frequently meets to discuss improvements in team members' skills during the projects (e.g., in retrospective meetings).
Teams are small (usually between 4 to 6 developers), self-organized and multidisciplinary.
The project team has autonomy to make technical decisions on the project.
The project stakeholders (including the client) are encouraged to think about their role and responsibilities in the project.
Good programming practices are adopted (e.g., collective coding, standardized coding, pair programming, code review, etc.).
Good testing practices are adopted (automated testing, test-driven development, etc.)
Data is collected for metrics to evaluate quality aspects of the produced artifacts and the product (e.g., cyclomatic complexity, number of code smells).
Data is collected for metrics to evaluate performance aspects of the agile development process (e.g., work in progress, velocity).
Data produced (task performer, task completion date, story points, etc.) throughout the development of the projects is stored in one (or more) data repository.
Decisions in projects are made based on data from one (or more) data repository.
The agile software development process is continuously evaluated and improved.
Data stored in the repository is used to improve the product and the agile software development process.
The organization has practices to share relevant knowledge to (agile) software development (e.g., internal lectures, tutorials, knowledge repositories, guild implementations).
The (agile) development process is aligned to the organization's business and this is perceived by the value delivery to the customer and her/his satisfaction with the delivered product.
